name: The Luck Knight, Lucky Knight, Champion of Tymora.
author: BlueSasquatch

posts.author: BlueSasquatch
posts.content:
Long time fan of NWN, played for years and then life got in the way. Picking up some D&D 5E pen and paper with some local friends, has me wanting to play NWN again, so I installed a Diamond edition on the laptop to run through campaigns with, ideally play my 5e character through nwn, to see how I like it. I know it's hard to compare 3e and 5e, but would like to attempt something similar. Couldn't find a build that felt right, wanted to see if anyone would want to put together a basic guide for such a character.


I actually RPed this character on a NWN server long ago, but I can't recall what build I used at all.

The Luck Knight

Dogma
One should be bold, for to be bold is to live. A brave heart and willingness to take risks beat out carefully wrought plans nine times out of ten. Place yourself in the hands of fate and trust your own luck. Bear and conduct yourselves as your own masters, showing your good or bad fortune as confidence in the Lady. Chase your own unique goals, and the Lady aids the chase. Without direction or goals, you soon know the embrace of Beshaba, For those on no set course are at the mercy of misfortune, which has no mercy at all.

My Character Back Story

Sir Felix Bellator
Washed ashore near a Temple to Tymora when he was a baby, no indication of lineage or signs of home, he was raised in the temple and developed a strong devotion to Tymora, considering himself blessed by her at birth. When he was old enough he joined the local militia, became addicted to gambling (although he views it as spreading Tymora's faith) and was kicked out of the militia and town after a mob formed over their distrust of him and his ability to frequently win games of chance. He continues to venture from town to town, in search of adventurers in need, and coin to be won, spreading the good word of his faith as a Champion of Tymora.

For RP purposes, my character is superstitious and cannot carry an even amount of coin, giving away one when needed to reach an odd number. He also will always strike an enemy an odd number of times, which can lead to taking another swing at that corpse. He flips a coin for non-vital decisions, or rolls a dice to help decide things, addicted gambler, overall optimistic and charismatic. Carries around good luck tokens.





1) Campaign Only, Original, then SOU and HOTU (I know SOU/HOTU are supposed to be played from level 1, so I may re-play the same character or try something different, for now its just the OC to relive)

2) Level cap - Not sure what is likely in the Campaigns, 30 I think?

3) Race preference - I went with Human for 5e but managed to get the DM to give me the Halfling Lucky Feat, which then allowed me to grab the Luck feat at level 4 for x2 the Luck. For this game, I figure that's not possible, so Halfling may be the way to go.

4) Class preference - Torn between a Fighter and a Paladin, while Tymora isn't a deity that has Paladins specifically, she does have Fellows of the Free Fate (https://forgottenrealms.fandom.com/wiki/Tymora) Possible Champion of Torm Combo?

5) Melee preference - Longsword or Bastard Sword with a Shield, or Two handed even, would rather STR over DEX here.

6) Range preference - DEX as a backup? Or just to bait them closer.

7) Weapon preference - If I recall bastard is 1 or 2 handed, so probably bastard with a shield for when my luck runs out.

8) Maximum item enhancement -Campaign, so +3 would be hard to find?

9) Spellcasting - Indifferent,

10) Custom factors - As luck-based as possible.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
First of all, welcome aboard, Blue Sasquatch!

Second of all, love the thinking and the back-story - flavour is so important to a build that isn't just robotic.

Third of all (don't worry, I've only got four of them), on the technical side, if you want a halfling then both long and bastard sword will be two-handed, so we might want to think about that one way or another. Also, and this is more about where you'll be playing, the Original Campaign will only get you to about level 17/18, while SoU and HotU will take you to about level 28. If you really want to have the big guns firing, you might want to think about following the OC with the Mines of Twin Summit modules (there's a thread with appropriate links in the Modules forum here), and SoU/HotU with Sands of Fate (likewise, see the Modules forum). Both of those avenues will get you comfortably to level 40, with time to enjoy it. However, if you want one story-arc to pan out and take you right up to level 36/37, then get the Aielund saga (also in the Modules forum).

Finally, fourth of all, the build! I was immediately drawn to CoT and Rogue from your description of the character, and I know of few finer examples than one of Mick Dagger's builds here: Halfling Champion

That said, it is Dex-based and dual-wields kukris, but is definitely worth a long hard look. If that doesn't appeal, I'm sure we can come up with something else.

Cheers

Got to dash (Real Life can be such a pain) - but just a couple of things:

While you're right about halflings having the Lucky feat naturally, humans get an extra feat anyway, so can take Luck of Heroes - ain't balance a wonderful thing! There will be more, but I have to go just now. Others will come in as well, I'm sure. Welcome back to the fold!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
The CoT does not have charisma-based saving throws, but it gains a steady +1 to all of his saves every two levels.
It is possible to combine the two (Paladin & CoT) & create a character that only fails his saving throws on "1".
The luck feat in Neverwinter Nights works differently than what you have in 5e, it is not a re-roll.
The closest thing to a re-roll mechanism is the bard's song in Icewind Dale, more than one bards can co-operate for this & eventually break the game like a chestnut.
Fighter/ Rogue or Bard/ CoT is the most versatile build in the game, it can cover almost everything.
Mick's Epic Brawler Champion is a very good build & can easily be adapted to Halfling if you like to play one.

You can see all bonuses that Hins have, here =>  https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Halfling

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Welcome to the guild BlueSasquatch!

The character you outline looks like a very fun character to roleplay.

Spoiler The concept of luck is not very well implemented as such in NWN. But many of the the rules that make up the game mechanics are based on dice rolls. (Attack rolls, saves rolls, DC checks, skill checks etc...) Most bonuses improve with higher character levels. But you can also do a lot by picking the right feats and skills.
I assume that you want your character to succeed most of the time, and roleplay that it is based on "luck". Of course we can skew the outcome with an appropriate build. We cannot make builds that are good at everything, or at least it takes us a little longer, but builds with a fairly good AB and AC combined with good saves can we do.

Spoiler Charisma has impact on some game mechanics. It is the basis of magic for sorcerers and bards. It is important for several feats used by divine characters (paladin, CoT, cleric, blackguard). Charisma boosts saves for paladins and blackguards. It also boosts several "social" skills such as persuade and bluff.
Ninja'd by Valerfor, but I post it anyway

Charismatic, big weapon, all sound good so far, but "light armor"?
No, that doesn't sound good in Neverwinter Nights world. You simply lose AC.
Of course, you could use a chain shirt & boost your dexterity to 18 with items & overall the difference would only be 1 AC, that is your choice.

BlueSasquatch wrote: Great to know Mick, thanks again! Like I said, I've never played bard before, not sure why but I always dismiss them as an option for some reason, perhaps I just never RP a bard, but I've narrow views of things sometimes.
//
I'll have to review the Bard some and see how to RP it, what spells that could pass for luck, I suppose I can sing Tymors praises while i smite the enemy.
In the build I have used the fighter and CoT classes to take care of the "knight" part of the character, providing combat related feats etc. CoT contributes to luck by boosting the saves. I have taken 6 different saves boosting feats to contribute to luck as well. 
Bard is there to represent the chaotic aspect of the character. I had no intention to create an artist of any kind. My intention was that you should roleplay him the way you have planned.
The songs are there (like Valerfor said) to manipulate luck. Several of the buffing and debuffing spells do the same.
Early on the bard levels contribute little to the character, except for adding skills and opening up for use of magic. Later on bard provides a powerful song and curse song. The spells come late and only a very few will have impact on the power of the build at that time, but many spells can add some flavour to gameplay. Bard and UMD opens up for use of scrolls and magic items early on. They can be roleplayed as lucky charms or things like that. 

Edit: If you are new to playing characters with bard in them, my bard guide (the one Stag promotes) will give some basic understanding of what the class has to offer.
